c74object.name: bach.-
c74object.description: Performs subtractions between lllls or between lllls and numbers.

outlet.digest: The subtraction of the two operands

objarg.name: right_operand
objarg.description: The optional argument is the right operand llll.

method.name: bang
method.description: Performs and outputs the calculation on the most recently received input lllls.

method.name: llll
method.description:
An llll in the first inlet will set the left llll for the subtraction, and will output the result; an llll in the second inlet will set the right llll for the subtraction, without outputting any result.
Unless one of the two operand lllls is a number, the operation is intended to be element-wise: position of elements of left and right elements must match in operations, both left and right lllls must have the same shape. If one of the two lllls is a single number, such number is used in the operation against all elements of the other llll (as when the scalarmode attribute is set to 1 in bach.expr).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

c74object.discussion: The abstraction is equivalent to a subtraction performed in a bach.expr object, with the scalarmode attribute set to 1.

entry.name: Outlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: The subtraction of the two operands.

entry.name: More details
entry.description: The abstraction is equivalent to a subtraction performed in a bach.expr object, with the scalarmode attribute set to 1.
